did.unittitle:
Martin Papers,
1862-1868.
did.abstract: Inventory includes papers, 1862-1868, of the Martin family of North Carolina, chiefly the correspondence of Major Thomas Alston Martin who served in the 13th North Carolina Infantry. Includes letters, 1862, of R. C. Martin written while serving in the Confederate Army. Many letters in the collection are written by women.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open to all researchers.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights/Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Before publishing quotations or excerpts from any materials, permission must be obtained from the Curator of Manuscripts and Rare Books, and the holder of the copyright, if not Swem Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: Thomas A Martin was from Franklin County, North Carolina. He enlisted as a Corporal in Co. E., 13th N. C. May 9, 1861. He served as a sergeant, Lt. and Capt. He was wounded in the hip at Gettysburg and was promoted to major January 19, 1865. Martin was paroled at Appomattox. [Source: Kirk, Robert K., Lee's Colonels: a biographical register of the Field Officers of the Army of Northern Virginia. Dayton, Ohio: Press of Morningside Bookshop, 1979]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: This collection contains papers of the Martin family of North Carolina. It is primarily composed of papers and correspondence with relatives in North Carolina and Virginia, 1862-1868, belonging to Major Thomas Alston Martin who served in the 13th North Carolina Infantry. Several letters date to the Civil War and refer to camp conditions. It includes letters, 1862, of R. C. Martin written while serving in the Confederate Army. Many of the letters were written by women.

arrangement.head: Organization
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into 2 series. Series 1 contains letters and series 2 contains miscellaneous items.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in chronological order by the dates on the letters.
